passages.text: It was a tough 2Q reporting season, with our pkgg/paperboard stocks down \(- 5\%\) vs the S&P 500 since 6/30. Given recent events and mindful of our ratings, we upgrade Silgan and International Paper to Buy from Neutral. Separately, we increase our containerboard (cbd; c'board) price forecasts which are already above consensus.

From our perch, the market is moving from "defense" (which had allowed packagers to keep up with the market through 1H) to more "risk-on." That said, post- 2Q reporting and stock performances show the market has little patience for below- expectation quarters and guides. BofA's Head of US Equity & Quant Strategy Savita Subramanian does like cyclicals and is underweight staples while recent Fed comments on rates are supportive.

Sporting a \(- 11 - 12x\) P/E on 25- 26 estimates and an implied flattish growth rate (v. averages closer to \(14x\) and \(- 1 - 2\%\) , respectively), we upgrade Silgan (SLGN) to Buy from Neutral. We saw less compelling valuation and upward catalysts into 2Q reporting but we think SLGN should be bought after it dropped over \(15\%\) on reduced earnings guidance, a call- out of weak bev- closure vols and food can- customer bankruptcy issues. SLGN is partly defensive (less aligned with our strategy call) because of food cans, but its sell- off and the potential for improved volumes supports a Buy. Other packaging Buys include Sealed Air (SEE), Sonoco (SON), and Graphic (GPK), which discount depressed growth rates and should benefit from an economic pickup.

We move to Buy on International Paper and now have Buys across our three c'board companies. As 2Q commentary suggested, there is important execution risk with IP, and consensus is muddied by its pulp divestiture. However, operating rates will now be over \(95\%\) in 2026 and we add another \(\) 40/\(ton to pricing for 3Q26 to our existing\) \ \(40/ton\) increase in 1Q26 - our average \(\) 60/\(ton increase exceeds consensus for\) \ \(20 - 30/ton\) (source: Visible Alpha). With significant capacity reductions by IP and others, (see last week's report here), Packaging Corp (PKG; Buy) benefits more cleanly (no restructuring). However, if we're right about pricing, this should overwhelm IP's near- term operating issues. We'll continue our ongoing channel checks and surveys.

Volume over the last six quarters, while positive, has been disappointing given the easy comparisons offered by the 3Q22- 4Q23 packaging recession. Aggregate volume growth remains a meager- \(1\%\) to \(3\%\) since the recession concluded. Several years ago, we wrote the sector's equities were akin to bonds masquerading as stocks given their good cash flows but limited growth. We'll return to this topic in upcoming reports - bottom line, we continue to believe value creation comes from effective capital allocation, value return, and leverage management. Large M&A has not frequently created value unless it first drives commercial benefits from growth, mix and/or pricing.

\(>>\) Employed by a non- US affiliate of BofAS and is not registered/qualified as a research analyst under the FINRA rules. Refer to "Other Important Disclosures" for information on certain BofA Securities entities that take responsibility for the information herein in particular jurisdictions. BofA Securities does and seeks to do business with issuers covered in its research reports. Exhibit 1: Paper/Forest Comparable Summary Valuation Data
Review of valuations for companies in Paper/Forest

Earnings season brought weaker stock performance, with our average packaging and paperboard stock down about 5% in our group versus the market since June 30. Many of our stocks were actually down 10% or more on reporting day, further illustrating this trend. However, with the "new season" (*); school, TV, foliage, etc.) at hand (and always mindful of our relative ratings and catalysts), we upgrade our views on Silgan, International Paper, and the broader containerboard market.
Source: Company filings, BofA Global Research estimates. Priced on 08/27/25.
Note: GEF EPS and P/E based on Class A shares; GEF market cap and EV/EBITDA based on Class A and B shares.

We move Silgan (SLGN) to Buy. SLGN got "clocked" following its 2Q earnings report – its stock declined -15%+ on an actual and relative basis on reporting day and it remains mired at relative lows. Weakness in hot-fill beverage closures (due to cooler weather earlier in the summer) and the impacts of a customer bankruptcy in food cans led us to lower our forecasts. To bake in some additional conservatism for 2026 (recalling the market's lack of patience discussed earlier), we take 1-2% points out of Metal Container (food can) volumes and 5c from our prior models as further precaution for demand elasticity due to higher steel can and consumer pricing, and risks from GLP-1 on demand (while not specific to SLGN, other companies called out weakness in consumption of snacks, confectionary and beer – signposts that GLP-1 remedies are impacting demand somewhat).

Do we love the market setup here? – it could be better, as we would view SLGN as partly a defensive stock given its food can and plastic bottle businesses and given some earnings headwinds. As mentioned earlier, our strategists prefer cyclicals. That said, the valuation dislocation relative to a "good, not great" quarter seems worse than other stocks we track, and our strategists are also saying value and SmidCaps could be back in vogue. While this framework could be applied to much of our coverage, we think it suits Silgan well. On valuation, along with trading 2-3x below its recent P/E peaks (and long-term, we see SLGN as a rerating story on closures), its implied growth rate is also relatively flat vs. what we would see as a more normal +1-2%.

Our PO moves to \(\) 57\(from\) \ \(53\) as we anticipate investors will take P/E multiples back to the mid- teens on an absolute basis and perhaps \(60 - 70\%\) on a relative basis once estimates and volumes return to trendline. Specifically, our PO is based on an average of a 15- 16x multiple on our 2025 EPS estimate (16- 17x prior), a 10- 11x multiple on our 2025 EBITDA, and a \(\) 450\(mn normal FCF. Our estimate for normalized FCF moves from\) \ \(400mn\) to \(\) 450mn\$ , in between the company's own long- term FCF guidance of \(\) 500mn\$ and its guidance for 2025 of \(\) 430mn\$ . Catalysts for 2H25 and 2026 should include a positive "pack" (harvesting), potential for more promotional activity in canned foods (albeit, while customers pass through higher pricing), strong canned wet petfood volumes, and some other positives. The table below illustrates that Silgan should see somewhat better than average growth v. peers (even excluding the Weener acquisition).

Exhibit 3: 2Q was not great for our sector but we assume \(\sim 1\%\) growth in 2025 across packagers in our base case forecasts Quarterly volume growth from 2023 to 2027E; Packaging growth should be \(\sim 1\%\) in 2H25

Source: Company reports, BofA Global Research. Note: Our volume estimates reflect estimated segment averages. IP growth reflects North America Corrugated Packaging volumes only.

As discussed in our recent report on containerboard capacity (see here for that report), operating rates in the sector could move well above \(95\%\) in 2026. The latest capacity change came from International Paper, which announced it will close its Riceboro and Savannah mills for a combined impact of \(- 1.5\mathrm{mn}\) tons, although this will be partially offset by an investment in additional capacity at its Riverdale mill.

As a result, we see it as likely prices will move beyond our previously forecast \(+\) 40/ton level and we now project a second increase of \(\) 40/\(ton for 2026, beginning in 3Q26. Our North America price forecast for IP (say,\)60/ton on average for 2026 combining the full - year\)40/ton and half - year \(\) 40/\(ton) looks to be above IP consensus\)- \$20 - 30/ton based on our review of Visible Alpha) which provides a stock catalyst. Looking back at history, investors must watch out for overstaying a bullish stock call relative to the pricing cycle (the market will frequently figure out the end of a pricing cycle before the sell - side), but our review suggests we could have 1 - 2x - turns of valuation tailwind for the subsector, still.
Exhibit 4: BofA Pulp, Paper, Board & Wood Products Price Forecasts, 2024-2027E Review of pricing forecasts for 2024-2027E
Source: Fastmarkets RISI / Pulp & Paper Week, BofA Global Research estimates. All prices per short ton.

The rising tide that we expect from operating rates and pricing should lift IP's boat and we reflect this in our ratings. Given our revised price forecasts our estimates for IP move to \(\) 3.25\(from\) \ \(3.00\) in 2026 and \(\) 4.20\(from\) \ \(3.60\) in 2027. Our 2025 estimate moves to \(\) 1.36\(from\) \ \(1.55\) to account for the divestiture of GCF and our PO moves to \(\) 57\(from\) \ \(55\)

The much- discussed 80/20 program is core to the way IP management is attempting to run the company differently than in past years. That said, it also underscores that there is execution risk with IP as it tries to transform itself. For example, IP volumes in North America were down \(- 4\%\) vs the market as it ultimately attempts to get back to flat- orbetter relative trends. IP is guiding its European EBITDA to \(- \mathbb{S}1\mathrm{bn}\) in 2025 (we are at \(\) 823\mathrm{mn}\$

Nearer term, IP consensus of \(\) 980\mathrm{mn}\$ includes \(- \mathbb{S}100–150\mathrm{mn}\) of GCF EBITDA, given our industry discussions. Based on 2Q commentary, IP seems to be guiding to roughly \(\) 875\mathrm{mn}\$ in EBITDA for 3Q with about \(\) 250\mathrm{mn}\$ from Europe ( \(- \mathbb{S}200\mathrm{mn}\) in 2Q plus \(- \mathbb{S}50\mathrm{mn}\) guided sequential improvement), \(\) 640\mathrm{mn}\$ in North America ( \(\) 515\mathrm{mn}$ in 2Q plus \(- \mathbb{S}125\mathrm{mn}\) guided sequential improvement) and \(\) 15\mathrm{mn}\$ of corporate expense. Discerning true IP earnings power and the level of street estimates is difficult given all the M&A.

Separately, the sale of GCF will only bring in proceeds of \(\) 1.5\mathrm{bn}\(below our previous estimate of\) \ \(1.7bn\) including \(\) 190\mathrm{mn}\$ of preferred to be issued by the buyer. Additionally, Europe c'board pricing declined in recent publications. We have tried to account for the GCF sale and Europe c'board price weakness in our models.

Separately, if we are correct with our forecasts, this should help other containerboard producers including Packaging Corp, rated Buy (PKG). Frankly, PKG should have a more linear benefit from pricing as it continues to grow, gain share, and have limited restructuring and integration headwinds, notwithstanding the pending, moderately- sized Greif (GEF; Neutral) containerboard acquisition, which we view as a positive. PKG also has no direct exposure to Europe.

PKG EPS estimates move to \(\) 11.45\(from\) \ \(11.05\) in 2026 and \(\) 12.45\(from\) \ \(11.50\) in 2027. Our 2025 estimate remains unchanged. Our PO for PKG moves to \(\) 240\(from\) \ \(222\) as we raise our normalized FCF estimate to \(\) 900\(mn from a current\) \ \(800mn\)

Our forecasts for IP and PKG increase largely due to the implications of an additional \(\) 40\(/ton increase we anticipate for 2026, as discussed earlier. Our estimates attempt to build - in some conservatism for increased operating costs as a partial offset to the pricing gains. Our PO increase for IP to\) \ \(57\) from \(\) 55\(, additionally balances increased earnings from the price increase partially offset by balance sheet adjustments due to lower - than - expected cash proceeds on the pulp divesture.

Our PO increase for Silgan is largely driven by our increased view of normalized FCF - upon further review of past comments and performance, we move to \(\) 450mn\(from a prior\) \ \(400mn\) estimate. The company had been guiding to \(\) 430mn\(for this year and\) \ \(500mn\) normalized and our revised estimate falls in that range (and looks doable). As noted, we shave our estimates by a nickel to incorporate food can demand elasticities due to higher retail pricing and other factors.

We rate International Paper a Buy. IP does have several risk factors associated with its 80/20 turnaround and the industry, while M&A and its transformation create muddiness relative to performance and consensus expectations. That said, we believe our industry price forecasts are above the street for 2026 and we see this as a positive catalyst for the shares.

We rate Silgan a Buy given its valuation, among other factors. The stock dropped significantly in 2Q despite reporting reasonably good results and concerns regarding closures volumes and a can customer's bankruptcy were overdone in the stock. Volumes should remain positive into 2H.

Our \(\) 10.00\(price objective (AU\) 15.50) is derived from a four - part valuation approach, which includes (1) a 13 - 15x calendarized 2025E P/E multiple, (2) an 10 - 11x calendarized 2025E EV/EBITDA multiple, (3) a normalized FCF estimate of\) \ \(1,800m\) , an estimated cost of equity of \(9\%\) and forecast rate of growth of \(0\%\) . We believe the multiples (in- line to a slight premium) are appropriate relative to peers given the company's quality, size, and low leverage.

Risks to our PO are: (1) plastic packaging markets' potential sustainability challenges, particularly in rigid plastic bottles, (2) food, beverage and other packaging fundamentals' potential to disappoint relative to expectations, (3) unfavorable resin price volatility relative to our forecasts could impact results despite contractual pass throughs, (4) competitive factors, (5) unfavorable volume and pricing trends relative to our forecasts, (6) unfavorable macroeconomic trends, (7) risk that the Berry Global acquisition is not successful. Should risk factors cited here and the company fundamentals prove more benign/favorable versus our forecasts, AMCR's results and its PO could significantly under- or outperform our expectations over time.

Our \(\) 175\(PO is based on a two - part valuation approach: (1) Sum - of - the - parts (SOTP) valuation based on our projection of ATR's 2025 segment results. Given our evaluation of peer and market multiples, we project ATR's Pharma business will be valued at 20 - 25x our 2025E EBITDA forecast given where peers currently trade. We value Aptar Closures at 8 - 9x EV/EBITDA and we value Aptar Beauty segment at an 8x multiple given a longer than expected rebound in the beauty and fragrance market. (2) Normalized FCF valuation which reflects our expectation that it will generate nearly\) \ \(400m\) of FCF on a normalized basis, an estimated COE of \(9\%\) , and a forecast growth rate of \(5\%\) .

Upside risks: (1) strength of ATR's project backlog given conversions to dispensing products, (2) specialty packagers' ability to surprise in performance in the mid- to- late cycle, (3) a stronger- than- expected recovery from Asian beverage market destocking, (4) depreciation of USD, (5) ATR's restructuring program which could add materially to forecasts.

Downside risks: (1) should consumer trends remain unfavorable for the stock, (2) acquisition risks, given ATR's balance sheet, (3) unfavorable resin swings, (4) unfavorable international growth and potential effects from coronavirus, (5) mgmt transitions, (6) should trends reverse in the policy or regulatory outlook for the US or other countries.

Our \(\) 4.10\(price objective is based on a three - part valuation approach, which takes (1) a 15 - 16x 2025E P/E multiple, (2) a 9 - 10x 2025E EV/EBITDA multiple and (3) our intrinsic free cash flow (FCF) valuation, which assumes\) \ \(200m\) of normalized FCF, \(9\%\) cost of equity, and a \(2\%\) growth rate. These multiples are consistent with comparable (similar growth expectations) company multiples.

Risks to our price objective are (1) AMBP's ability to compete with larger well- established peers, (2) growth, pricing and valuation considerations should volumes slow, (3) potential for customer concentration, (4) end- market mix, (5) raw material availability in light of periodic supply- chain disruptions and the need to pass through primary raw

materials (i.e. aluminum can sheet), (6) leverage relative to other rigid packaging companies, (7) energy cost volatility in Europe, and (8) Potential restructuring at the Ardagh Group level, (9) An additional risk arising in early 2025 from the Surgeon General's recommendation for warning labels on alcoholic beverage products, and the potential effect on customers' volumes.

As with all paper/forest and packaging companies a multitude of micro and macro factors are at work and, coupled with operational leverage, results could be better- or worse- than- expected with downside and upside risks to our PO should fundamentals wind up above or below expectations.

Our \(206\) price objective is derived from a three- part valuation approach, which includes the use of (1) a 19- 21x 2025E P/E multiple, (2) a 12- 13x 2025E EV/EBITDA multiple, and (3) our intrinsic free cash flow (FCF) valuation, which estimates \(825mn\) of normalized FCF (please see our free cash flow model for additional information), \(9\%\) cost of equity and a \(5\%\) growth rate. Based on history, we think our valuation multiples are appropriate for a late- cycle period with limited inflation.

Risks to our price objective are (1) risk relative to AVY's ability to execute on its cost reduction plans, (2) volume and pricing trends in core Materials Group and Solutions Group segments, (3) dependence on emerging economies, (4) dilution from radio frequency identification (RFID) investments, (5) unfavorable volume and pricing trends, (6) unfavorable macroeconomic environment, (7) variability in governmental policy.

Our \(68\) price objective is based on a three- part valuation approach, which takes: (1) a 17- 19x 2025E P/E multiple, (2) a sum- of the parts with a 10- 11x multiple on North & Central America, 12- 13x on EMEA, 11x on South America, and 10- 11x on Other and (3) our intrinsic free cash flow (FCF) valuation, which assumes \(1.1bn\) of normalized FCF, \(9\%\) cost of equity and a \(3\%\) growth rate. Multiple ranges higher vs past levels given packaging group valuations and the growth trajectory offered by the beverage can market.

Downside risks to our PO are (1) increasing operational challenges from new capacity onboarding, (2) potentially higher competition arising from new entrants, (3) BALL's ability to realize benefits from prior capital spending (e.g., new capacity, custom cans, productivity, etc.), (4) input cost volatility including energy cost volatility in Europe, (5) overseas/emerging market risks (for ex., currency), (6) demand trends in beverages, including the risks to overall valuation, demand and pricing should growth slow, (7) seasonal- weighting of full- year earnings to the key 2Q/3Q period, (8) potential regulatory changes in the US and elsewhere, (9) risk arising in early 2025 from the Surgeon General's recommendation for warning labels on alcoholic beverage products, & the potential effect on customers' volumes.
And there are numerous macro & other risks around volumes, pricing, input costs & other factors that could negatively affect fundamental & stock price performance.

Our \(107\) PO is based on the average of (a) a free cash flow (FCF) valuation based on our estimate of \(350mn\) in FCF, a calculated cost of equity of \(10\%\) and forecast rate of growth of \(3\%\) , (b) a sum- of- the- parts (SOTP) value that values BCC's Wood segment at 5x EBITDA (which is consistent with Wood multiples at this stage of the cycle) and \(0.7x\) sales while its Building Materials Distribution segment will be valued at \(8x\) and \(0.8x\) , respectively, in- line with peers with similar growth. We then discount this valuation back to derive our 12 month PO.

Downside risks to our price objective being achieved are: (1) a slower housing recovery, (2) downwards commodity pricing volatility, (3) demand, supply-chain, (4) distribution business inventory and inflation trends, (5) potential volatility in actual performance relative to consensus given operating and financial leverage, (6) potential increases in Brazilian exports of plywood to the US.

Upside risks are: (1) increases in single and multi- family construction, and/or greater- than- expected usage of BCC products in construction, (2) upwards commodity pricing volatility, (3) reduced imports of plywood from Brazil.

To the extent that the points above are more negative than expected, BCC's results and stock price could wind up below our forecasts. Similarly, to the extent that the points above are more positive than expected, BCC results and stock price could wind up above our forecasts.

Our PO of \(\) 120\(is based on our 2025 estimates and averaging the fair values derived from (1) a 17 - 18x'25E P/E multiple, (2) a sum - of - the - parts (SOTP) valuation which values the Americas Beverage segment at 10 - 11x EBITDA, European Beverage at 11 - 13x, Asia Pacific at 8 - 10x, Transit Packaging at 9x and Other at 6x, (3) our intrinsic FCF valuation, which assumes\) \ \(800mm\) normalized FCF, a \(9\%\) cost of equity and \(2\%\) growth. Multiples are above recent average given our view of CCK's attractive valuation.

Downside risks: (1) weather uncertainties during key seasonal periods in 2Q- 3Q, (2) asbestos liabilities could present a greater drain on cash flow than we currently expect, (3) FX translation, as majority of sales are outside US, (4) increasing investment, particularly in EM, (5) shr loss to aseptic or plastic/flexible pkgg or other materials, particularly in food can ops, (6) unfav. demand trends in key food & bev end mkts, & the overall risks to valuation, demand & price should growth slow, (7) unfav. vol & price trends, (8) potential gov policy & regulatory changes in US & elsewhere, (9) Add'l risk arising in early 25 from Surgeon General's recommendation for warning labels on alcoholic bev products, & the potential effect on customers' vols.

There are many macro risks & other risks around vols, price, input costs & other factors could negatively affect fundamental & price perf. Should these factors prove more constructive than expected, CCK's perf/PO could exceed our ests.

Our \(\) 28\(PO is based on the average of (a) an EV/EBITDA valuation calculated by applying a 7 - 8x EV/EBITDA multiple to our 2025 EBITDA estimate (our multiple is consistent with where comparable companies have traded and we believe this is fair given similar growth expectations), (b) a P/E valuation calculated by applying a 15x P/E multiple to our 2025 EPS estimate (our multiple is consistent with where comparable companies have traded and fair in our view given similar growth expectations), (c) a free cash flow (FCF) valuation based on our 2026 estimate, a calculated cost of equity of 10% and forecast rate of growth of 2%.

Risks to our PO: (1) closing and integration risks associated with the acqs, (2) demand trends in food & bev and other GPK end mkts, (3) potential volatility in fiber, energy, other input costs, (4) paper/board sector volatility & demand trends, including trade flow volatility created by FX, (5) fundamental trends that could be worse than expected, (6) various factors associated with its new CRB machine, (7) An additional risk arising in early 2025 from the Surgeon General's recommendation for warning labels on alcoholic beverage products, and the potential effect on customers' volumes.
Also, industry & economic trends could prove weaker or stronger than modeled. Greater- than- expected weakness could lead to valuation multiples and earnings below our fcsts,
even as better-than expected trends could lead to a higher relative multiple premium & stock price.

Our \(\) 77\(PO for Class A shares is based on (1) a 14 - 16x calendarized 2025E P/E, (2) a 8 - 9x calendarized 2025E EV/EBITDA which derives a value for the combined equity market cap of Class A and B shares. Relative to these points, we believe the multiples (a discount versus market and peers) are appropriate versus past normalized ranges (PE of 10 - 17x) and 5 - 10x EV/EBITDA for peers, given Greif's more cyclical business mix and current macro and other risks. We assume the elimination of a premium or discount to our combined equity value will occur equally for Class A and B, driving our target for Class A shares on this method, and (3) our intrinsic FCF valuation assumes\) \ \(300mm\) normalized FCF, \(9\%\) cost of equity and \(2\%\) growth rate.

Risks to our PO: (1) unfavorable demand in GEF's markets and geographies, (2) volatility in steel, resin, OCC, energy and other inputs, (3) acquisition/integration risks, (4) Class B share ownership, which retains voting power, is \(70\%\) held by insiders, (5) Regulatory review or litigation, including with plastics, jerry cans, drums and their related fabrication and products, (6) trade policy, (7) impacts from the planned divestiture of containerboard.

Our \(\) 57\(price objective is based on an average of (a) our 2026E EPS forecast and a P/E of 15x, which is at the high end of historical ranges, (b) a normalized free cash flow (FCF) estimate of\) \ \(1.75bn\) , a calculated cost of equity of \(9\%\) and forecast rate of growth of \(2\%\) , (c) our 2026E EBITDA forecast and a EV/EBITDA multiple of 9 - 11x, which is at the high end of historical ranges. Given the track record of CEO Andy Silvermail and our assessment of the logic in his approach to running the company, we believe that IP should be valued towards the high - end of its past valuation ranges as well as a level approaching the best - in - class competitors.

Risks to our price objective are (1) the broader employment & macro picture, (2) paper/board sector volatility & demand trends, (3) wastepaper/input cost volatility, (4) trends in the US\$ and its effect on trade flows, (5) emerging market risk, (6) operational risks related to investment projects, (7) IP's pension, (8) the potential for new capacity to come into the market, (9) the performance/integration of DS Smith post- merger, (10) industry cycles in North America and Europe, (11) and potential volatility coming from any future Administration policy changes. Fundamental trends could wind up worse than expected, causing further downside to the shares relative to our PO. Better performance or macro news could cause the shares to perform better than our price objective.

Our PO of \(\) 28\(is based on a simple average of P/E, EV/adjusted EBITDA, and a normalized FCF valuation. (1) Our P/E valuation of\) \ \(30\) is based on 15- 17x '26E P/E, (2) our EV/EBITDA valuation of \(\) 29\(is based on 9 - 11x estimated'25 EBITDA (a nearer - term horizon given the sensitivity in equity returns to KRT growth, cost and margin assumptions), and (3) our intrinsic FCF valuation of\) \ \(25\) assumes \(\) 45\(mn normalized FCF, a 12% cost of equity and 3% growth. In our calculation, we consider 2025 and 2026 estimates and the average of fair values derived from KRT's historical trading range and a weighted average of foodservice distributors (90%) and packaging companies (10%).

Risks: (1) strong competition can lead to pricing pressures, (2) high dividend payouts versus FCF, (3) significant KRT ownership by management, creating liquidity risks, (4) smaller company considerations, (5) macro and sector concerns around labor market, consumer sentiment, and demand (6) future dilution from outstanding options and warrants, and (7) reliance on bubble- tea- market exposure (15- 20% of sales). We also note energy, commodity, geographic and other market risks. Industry and economic

trends could prove weaker or stronger than modeled. Greater- than- expected risks could lead to valuation multiples and earnings below our forecasts, while demand and other fundamental risks could prove less significant, and KRT results could exceed our forecasts.

Our \(\) 83\$ PO is based on an average of (a) a normalized free cash flow (FCF) estimate of \(\) 433\mathrm{mn}\(a calculated cost of equity of\) 11\% \(and forecast rate of growth of\) 3\% \(, (b) a SOTP value, using our evaluation of normal EBITDA, which is an average of historical periods 2016- 24 and our forecasts through'25E. We project LPX's OSB segment will be valued at 5x our 2025E EBITDA forecast and its Siding segment will be valued at 16x EBITDA given building product/siding peer comps. We apply 6- 8x EBITDA multiples to its other businesses. Separately, we value LPX's OSB business at 2x sales, its siding business at 3.5x sales and its other businesses at 1- 2x sales. We assume the average of our EV/EBITDA and EV/Sales valuations, and then discount this to derive our 12- month PO.

Downside risks: (1) the broader housing picture, (2) weak demand and supply- chain, (3) changes in average home size, (4) OSB supply/demand dynamics, (5) cost volatility (wood fiber, resin, and foreign exchange), (6) operational risks associated with the expansion of LPX's siding segment, (7) regulatory and policy changes, and (8) supply/demand and market risks in Siding, and across LPX's business.
Upside risks: Should housing and related demand trends or supply/demand in LPX's various product markets prove better- than- expected, LPX stock could exceed our PO.

Our \(\) 14\$ PO is based on an average of P/E, EV/EBITDA and intrinsic free cash flow (FCF) valuations. We use a 9- 11x 2025E P/E multiple, a 5- 6x 2025E EV/EBITDA multiple, and our intrinsic FCF valuation, which assumes \(\) 250\mathrm{m}\$ normalized FCF, \(10\%\) cost of equity, and a \(- 1\%\) growth rate. Multiples are in line with OI's historical averages - a valuation re- . rating will likely require stronger volume trends.

Risks to our PO are: (1) unfavorable demand and pricing, (2) the potential for pension claims to consume greater amounts of earnings or cash flow, (3) unfavorable international market volatility and FX risks, (4) production and operations risks as OI consolidates its footprint, (5) risks in Mexican pricing and pack mix, (6) potential governmental policy changes in the US and other portions of the world, (7) An additional risk arising in early 2025 from the Surgeon General's recommendation for warning labels on alcoholic beverage products, and the potential effect on customers' volumes.

As is the case with all our coverage, packaging and paper/forest stocks are highly sensitive to macro, FX, commodity inflation and other factors which could create variances with our forecasts and POs. Similarly, should the factors discussed above prove less negative or more positive to forecasts, OI's price could exceed our PO.

Our \(\) 240\$ price objective is based on an average of (a) a 20x multiple on our 2025E EPS forecast, (b) a normalized free cash flow (FCF) estimate of \(\) 900\mathrm{m}\$ , a calculated cost of equity of \(9\%\) and forecast rate of growth of \(5\%\) , (c) a sum- of- the- parts (SOTP) value, based on forecast midcycle EBITDA or per ton(ne) replacement values.

Risks to our price objective being achieved are (1) PKG's leverage to economic cycles, (2) containerboard market volatility and demand trends, (3) input cost volatility, (4) demand, supply- chain and other risks created by the Covid- 19 pandemic, (5) potential structural changes in the economy, (6) the potential for mill or converting operations to perform less well than anticipated, (7) the potential for new capacity to come into the market, (8)

volatility from policy changes by the Administration, (9) potential execution and other negatives with the purchase of Greif's containerboard. While we've tried to be conservative in our modeling, fundamental trends could wind up worse than expected, causing downside risk to the shares relative to our price objective. Similarly, PKG results could wind up stronger than our forecasts, causing the shares to move beyond our PO.

Our \(\) 50\(PO is based on: (a) an assumed mid - cycle dividend yield of 3\% and dividend of\) \ \(1.80\) /share, (b) a 19- 21x mid- cycle AFFO multiple, and (c) a sum- of- the- parts (SOTP) value. Our SOTP model values PCH's Resources business based on our estimates of the per acre values for its timberlands, and values its Wood Products business based on our forecast for mid- cycle EBITDA and applying a 5x EV/EBITDA multiple. Meanwhile, we value its Real Estate operations based on the average premium generated over time, and assuming properties sold are ultimately replaced with other timberlands.

Risks to our PO being achieved are: (1) Interest rate trends, (2) Housing market weakness, which can impact PCH's Wood Products and Real Estate operations, as well as timberland profits, (3) Broader housing and economic trends, which can impact timberland and REIT valuations, including the threat of deflation, (4) Dividend trends, (5) Demand, supply chain and other risks lingering from the Covid- 19 pandemic and its aftermath, (6) Regulations on tax status of REITs. Upside risks to our PO are better- than- expected improvement in the housing market and dividend trends.

While we have tried to be conservative in our modeling, certain fundamental trends could wind up worse than expected, causing further downside to the shares relative to our price objective. Similarly, PCH performance could prove better than our forecast, lifting the shares above our PO.

Our \(\) 41\(price objective is derived from a three - part valuation approach, which includes: (1) a 13 - 15x 2025E P/E multiple, (2) a 9 - 10x 2025E EV/EBITDA multiple, and (3) our intrinsic free cash flow (FCF) valuation, which assumes\) \ \(400m\) of normalized FCF, \(10\%\) cost of equity, and a \(3\%\) growth rate. Our target multiples are based on SEE's past trading history and also peer multiples. SEE has been able to trade in the high teens to low twenties on a P/E basis, and a premium to the market when fundamentals improve.

Downside risks to our price objective are (1) risks relative to the company's ability to manage pricing and spreads, given (2) energy volatility, resin price volatility and agricultural market risks, (3) international business risks (significant sales are derived abroad), including FX and emerging market trends, (4) competitive and other factors negatively impacting volume to a greater degree than expected, (5) risks relative to execution of the company's transformation strategies over the last several years, (6) challenges associated with management transitions.

Overall, energy and commodity volatility represent ongoing risks for packaging companies. Industry and economic trends could prove weaker or stronger than we modeled. Greater- than- expected weakness could lead to valuation multiples and earnings that are below our forecasts.

Our \(\) 57\(price objective (PO) is based on a 15 - 16x 2025E P/E multiple, a 10 - 11x 2025E EV/EBITDA multiple, and our intrinsic FCF valuation, which assumes\) \ \(450m\) normalized FCF, \(9\%\) cost of equity, and a \(1\%\) growth rate. We believe SLGN should trade about in line with to slightly below its packaging peers given its relatively defensive profile.
Downside risks: (1) potential for metal cans to lose a greater amount of share over time, (2) potential for raw material costs to swing sufficiently so as to alter normal purchasing

patterns, (3) food can business' heavy seasonality during 2Q/3Q pack, (4) SLGN's ability to integrate its recent acquisitions, (5) operational considerations related to SLGN's new metal and plastic packaging ops, (6) risks related to policy changes.

Energy and commodity volatility represent ongoing risks for packaging companies. We have tried to forecast accurately. However, industry and economic trends could prove weaker or stronger than we modeled.

Our Price Objective of US\(59 / GBp 4421 is based on 8.2x 2026E EBITDA. This is broadly in line with US- listed packaging peers' average EV/EBITDA multiple. We view this as a fairly conservative approach as we believe Smurfit WestRock could re- rate to trade ahead of peers in time should SW management (legacy Smurfit Kappa management) be successful in bringing the same returns/value focus it embodied at the legacy Smurfit Kappa to bear on the acquired legacy WestRock assets.

Downside risks are: 1) Integration of the legacy Smurfit Kappa (SKG) and WestRock (WRK) businesses could be more challenging, take longer and/or cost more than expected. 2) The expected synergies of the merger could be delayed or not realised. 3) SW operates in a cyclical industry (paper and packaging) and both volumes (demand) and prices could decline, negatively impacting SWs earnings and cash flows. 4) Overcapacity in paper and paper- based packaging products could weigh on paper prices and SW margins. 5) Smurfit WestRock may need to invest more than we currently forecast in order to keep its asset base of paper mills competitive. 6) Financial risk: The net debt position of Smurfit WestRock is higher than SKG was as a standalone business. This could constrain the ability of SW to execute its strategy.

Our \(62 PO\) is derived from a three- part valuation approach, which includes: (1) a 13- 14x 2025E P/E multiple, (2) a 9- 10x 2025E EBITDA multiple, and (3) our intrinsic free cash flow (FCF) valuation, which assumes \(\) 550\(mn of normalized FCF, 9\%\) cost of equity, and 0% growth rate. The P/E and EBITDA multiples are consistent with past valuation multiples within packaging and are fair in our view given similar growth expectations.

Downside risks to our PO are: (1) potential volatility in old corrugated container (OCC) prices, (2) execution on restructuring & integration initiatives, (3) integration of present acquisitions, (4) periodic volatility in its business, (5) execution of its consumer/growth strategies in packaging, (6) unexpected volume & pricing trends, (7) macroeconomic trends, (8) potential trend reversals related to Administration policies, (9) M&A factors, both as impact SON's efforts to deleverage, as well as customers' product marketing plans. In addition, energy & commodity cost volatility represent ongoing risk for all packaging companies.

Upside risks to our PO are: (1) SON's ability to acquire businesses accretively, making our forecasts too pessimistic, driving SON above our PO, (2) Additionally, should vols accelerate while input costs stay benign, this could lead to higher earnings than we expect & result in the stock exceeding our PO, (3) Factors noted earlier could play out in a way that causes results to exceed our fcst and drive the shares above our PO.

Our \(\) 44\(price objective is based on an average of (a) a 9x multiple on our 2025E EPS forecast, which is within the range in which paper companies have traded, (b) a normalized FCF estimate of around\) \ \(179mn\) , a calculated cost of equity of \(8\%\) and forecast rate of decline of \(- 3\%\) , (c) our sum- of- the- parts (SOTP) value, based on forecast midcycle EBITDA values and applying multiples of 4- 6x across the regions.
Downside risks to our PO: (1) Broader employment and macro trends, (2) Paper sector

volatility and demand trends, (3) Changes in the cost or availability of key inputs, energy and transportation, (4) Demand, supply chain and other risks created by the pandemic and its aftermath, (5) Potential cash outflow related to Brazilian tax rulings, (6) Emerging market risk, including potential for volatility in Latin America, (7) Potential for supply/demand imbalances in UCFS, (8) Volatility in macro and micro factors and the earnings leverage that exists could mean fundamental trends wind up worse than expected, causing further downside to the shares relative to our PO.

Our \(\) 32\(PO is based on the average of (a) an assumed mid - cycle dividend yield of 2.0% and dividend of\) \ \(0.80\) /share, (b) a 19- 21x mid - cycle AFFO multiple, and (c) a sum - of - the - parts (SOTP) value. Our SOTP model values WY's Timberlands business based on our estimates of the per acre values for its timberlands, and values its Wood Products business based on our forecast for mid - cycle EBITDA and applying a 5x EV/EBITDA multiple. Meanwhile, we value its Real Estate operations based on the average premium generated over time, and assuming properties sold are ultimately replaced with other timberlands.

Risks to our PO being achieved are (1) weak employment, (2) weak housing fundamentals, (3) regulations on the tax status of REITs - given WY's REIT status, some elements of the company's future performance (i.e., tax rate, corporate expense) could prove difficult to forecast, (4) Emerging market and FX trends, which could impact demand and pricing for WY timber, (5) dividend trends, (6) trends in China. As with all of our stocks, WY will be sensitive to changes in the domestic and global macro outlook, input cost trends, and potential policy and regulatory changes.

FUNDAMENTAL EQUITY OPINION KEY: Opinions include a Volatility Risk Rating, an Investment Rating and an Income Rating. VOLATILITY RISK RATINGS, indicators of potential price fluctuation, are: A - Low, B - Medium and C - High. INVESTMENT RATINGS reflect the analyst's assessment of both a stock's absolute total return potential as well as its attractiveness for investment relative to other stocks within its Coverage Cluster (defined below). Our investment ratings are: 1 - Buy stocks are expected to have a total return of at least \(10\%\) and are the most attractive stocks in the coverage cluster; 2 - Neutral stocks are expected to remain flat or increase in value and are less attractive than Buy rated stocks and 3 - Underperform stocks are the least attractive stocks in a coverage cluster. An investment rating of 6 (No Rating) indicates that a stock is no longer trading on the basis of fundamentals. Analysts assign investment ratings considering, among other things, the 0- 12 month total return expectation for a stock and the firm's guidelines for ratings dispersions (shown in the table below). The current price objective for a stock should be referenced to better understand the total return expectation at any given time. The price objective reflects the analyst's view of the potential price appreciation (depreciation).
Investment ratingTotal return expectation (within 12-month period of date of initial rating)Ratings dispersion guidelines for coverage clusterR2Buy≥ 10%≤ 70%Neutral≥ 0%≤ 30%UnderperformN/A≥ 20%
R2Ratings dispersions may vary from time to time where BofA Global Research believes it better reflects the investment prospects of stocks in a Coverage Cluster.

INCOME RATINGS, indicators of potential cash dividends, are: 7 - same/higher (dividend considered to be secure), 8 - same/lower (dividend not considered to be secure) and 9 - pays no cash dividend. Coverage Cluster is comprised of stocks covered by a single analyst or two or more analysts sharing a common industry, sector, region or other classification(s). A stock's coverage cluster is included in the most recent BofA Global Research report referencing the stock.
